title: Ferrets (cont.)
detail:
• No blood groups, so no typing necessary for safe transfusion
• Sexual maturity at 9-12 mo; females are induced ovulators and seasonally polyestrous, may die of estrogen toxicity if not bred/spayed; males have os penis
• 2 litters/year, 2-17 kits each time, born hairless and blind
• Spayed at 5-6 weeks to avoid risk of estrogen disease
• Hypoglycemia risk for older ferrets due to insulinoma

title: Ferret injections and blood collection
detail:
• Blood collection: Jugular or cranial vena cava (b/w manubrium and 1st rib); ceph or saph possible for small samples
• IV catheter: Cephalic or lateral saphenous
• IO catheter: Proximal femur (only for shock)
• IM: Quadriceps
• Fluid therapy w crystalloid and colloids, maintenance requirements like cats

title: Ferret anesthesia and analgesia
detail:
• Iso (1-3) and sevoflurane (3-5) + premed w ace, benzos, ketamine, opioids (if longer surgery)
• Butorphanol for mild pain; opioids for analgesia, B most common for moderate pain, hydro- and oxymorphone can also be used; tramadol for moderate to severe and oral at home analgesia; gaba for neuropathic pain; meloxicam as NSAID; lidocaine and bupivacaine for blocks
• Hypothermia risk due to size

title: Ferret diseases
detail:
• Hyperadrenocorticism: Due to hyperplasia (enlargement) of adrenal tissue and resulting secretion of sex hormones (as opposed to excess cortisol in dogs and cats); very common in middle to old age
• Signs: Alopecia starting at the tail, increased yellowing of fur, muscular atrophy, pruritus, vulvar enlargement, increased aggression and musky odor, prostatitis
• Tx: Synthetic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH analog), a GnRH superantagonist, melatonin implants, surgical removal of adrenal glands
• Lymphoma: Caused by infection, genetics, env.
• Signs: Anorexia, weight loss, lethargy, palpable lymph nodes, nodules in liver, mild anemia, lymphopenia
• Tx: Chemo (e.g. prednisone)
• Insulinoma: Pancreatic beta-cell tumors; most common neoplasia
• Signs: Episodic weakness, ataxia, seizures, collapse w quick recovery
• Tx: Surgical excision, prednisone, corn syrup/honey oral rub
• Ibuprofen toxicity can cause neurological symptoms like ataxia, coma, and tremors
• Green slime disease (coronaviral diarrhea) presents w severe green diarrhea, anorexia, weakness, dehydration, and emaciation

title: Ferret diseases (cont.)
detail:
• Human influenza: Ferrets can infect humans and vice versa; causes listlessness, anorexia, pyrexia, sneezing, nasal discharge; treated w fluid therapy, gastric protectants, antihistamines, cough suppressants, antibiotics
• Aleutian disease (parvovirus) presents as slow wasting, melena, splenomegaly, pyrexia, posterior paresis, tremors, death; no treatment or vaccine
• Estrogen-induced aplastic anemia: Due to prolonged periods of estrus causing toxic response in bone marrow, leading to reduced RBC production; signs incl. swollen vulva, dysuria, alopecia, petechial hemorrhage, anorexia, pale mucous membranes, depression; treated w spay, blood transfusion, GnRH agonists, vit B and iron
• Epizootic catarrhal enteritis: Young are carriers, give to older ferrets, so iso recommended for newcomers); causes green, tarry diarrhea, lethargy, anorexia, depression; treated w supportive care, fluid therapy, gastric protectants, antibiotics
• Canine distemper: Aerosol exposure or contact w conjunctival and nasal exudates, urine, feces; incubation period of 7-10 days; almost always fatal
• Classic ferret adrenal disease presents w alopecia at the tail tip, symmetrical alopecia along the trunk of the body, intense pruritus, enlarged vulva

title: Hedgehogs
detail:
• Insectivore, solitary (no more than 1 male), nocturnal
• Induced ovulators starting at 8 weeks, but shouldn’t breed until 6 mo; common to cannibalize young
• Need exercise (wheels), foraging (crickets in bedding); prone to obesity
• Sedation or anesthesia necessary for exam to avoid rolling into a ball
• Signs of pain/distress include weight loss w decreased appetite, lethargy, reduced activity, change in fecal appearance and output, more hiding, guarding body part, hissing or screaming in extreme distress
• Can carry Salmonella, which is zoonotic
• Neoplasia (oral squamous cell carcinoma, mammary gland and uterine adenocarcinoma) and dental disease common
• Self-anointing: Ass. w smells and seeing animals; looks like a seizure—stiff and contorted, licking motions, salivating—but is normal

title: Hedgehog injections and blood collection
detail:
• Blood collection: Cranial vena cava; jug, ceph, or saph possible
• IV catheter: Hard to obtain and maintain so not preferred
• IO catheter: Femur or tibia preferred method of catheterization
• IM: Epaxial muscles or thigh region
• SC: Between the spines or in furred regions

title: Hedgehog anesthesia and analgesia
detail:
• Induction w mask (5 iso, 8 sevo), but premed w anxiolytics reduces stress (ketamine, diazepam-midazolam, dexmedetomidine)
• Maintenance w mask (2-3 iso, 3-5 sevo) or intubation; 18-20 G catheter can be used for tube if 1.5 mm not available
• Butorphanol for mild to moderate pain; B for moderate pain (6-8 hours), hydromorphone, oxymorphone, morphine for moderate to sever pain; NSAIDs like meloxicam; gaba for neuropathic pain; lidocaine and bupivacaine for blocks

title: Hedgehog diseases
detail:
• Respiratory diseases: Can be caused by bacteria (Bordetella, Mycoplasma, Pasteurella), lungworm infections (Capillaria, Crensoma) through ingestion of an intermediate host like snails, thoracic neoplasia, cardiac disease, or environmental stress (cold env, dusty bedding)
• Signs: Coughing, wheezing, lethargy, dyspnea, increased lung sounds, inappetence, nasal discharge
• Tx: Antibiotics, bronchodilators, anthelmintics as needed
• Dermatitis and alopecia: Fleas, ticks, mites (Caparinia tripilis, Sarcoptes spp, Demodex spp), dermatophyte infections
• Signs: Cutaneous lesions, scratching, anemia, loss of spines (denuding), visual ectoparasites
• Tx: Ivermectin or selamectin for lice and mites, griseofulvin for dermatophytes, antibiotics for infection
• Cardiac disease: DCM is common, leads to CHF
• Signs: Lethargy, dyspnea, weight loss, heart murmur, ascites
• Tx: Dietary restrictions, digoxin, furosemide, enalapril
• Hepatic lipidosis w lethargy, inappetence, icterus, diarrhea is common

title: Birds
detail:
• Many adaptions for weight reduction and flight ability—lack of teeth, hollow (pneumatic) bones like humerus and femur, short GI tract, air sacs, high metabolic rate, oviparity, feathers
• No diaphragm, one cavity called coelomic for all organs; liver sits close to apex of the heart
• Visual senses extremely developed, smell (except scavangers) and taste are poor; rods/cones, upper/lower/nictating eyelids; eyes move independent from one another and head rotates 360; pupils attach to voluntary striated muscle (as opposed to involuntary smooth)
• Larger heart, larger nucleated RBCs relative to body size
• Blood volume is 10% of the body weight; a healthy bird can only lose ≤10% of its blood volume
• 5% of body weight can be tube fed at one time

title: Birds (cont.)
detail:
• Heterophil (functionally similar to neutrophil) is the most numerous leukocyte in bird blood; eosinophils and basophils are rare, lymphocytes are present
• No bladder: urine excreted as uric acid and voided w feces thru cloaca, which is the final holding area for feces, urine/urates, and eggs before being expelled thru the vent
• Have choana, which is an opening at the roof of the mouth that connects the trachea to the sinuses and the nares; choanal slit is located on the roof of the mouth and has many sharp papillae protruding from it
• Dehydration assessed via venous refill time by depressing the cutaneous ulnar vein (should refill instantly)
• Pygostyle is a bony plate formed by fusing of several of the 12 coccygeal vertebrae that supports tail feathers

title: Feathers
detail:
• Feather types include contour (body/flight feathers), plume (down/powder down), and semiplume (bristles/hairs in some species); molting occurs at least once a year, doesn’t stop flight; primary feathers can be trimmed to prevent flight
• Blood feathers are growing feathers; blood is seen in the proximal part of the shaft during the entire growth phase but dries up once feather is fully grown; should be pulled and pressure applied at the follicle to stop any bleeding
• Pterylae are the areas where feathers lie on the body (tracts where feathers originate); apterylae are featherless areas
• Rectrices are tail feathers; remiges are wing feathers
• Barbules are parts of the feather that help keep the feather pulled together neatly
• Rachis of a feather is filled w blood capillaries during growth but as it matures it becomes hollow

title: GI system of birds
detail:
• Some birds (poultry, songbirds) have crops (ingluvies), which are temporary storage pouches in the esophagus; proximal esophagus leads to the crop while distal esophagus leads to stomach
• No epiglottis in birds
• GI system starts w the oral cavity, then moves to crop, to proventriculus (grandular stomach), to the gizzard (ventriculus)

title: Respiratory system of birds
detail:
• No vocal cords; sound is produced by the syrinx at the base of trachea
• Most efficient gas exchange system among vertebrates—doesn’t occur in alveoli but in air capillaries that form a close network and intertwine w blood capillaries so exchange occur at every point of the breathing cycle
• Lungs don’t expand during inspiration due to cartilage; two breaths make air move because lungs have unidirectional flow
• 1st inhale makes air moves thru abdominal air sacs, 1st exhale forces air to the lungs w abdominal contraction
• 2nd inhale makes air leave lungs to cranial air sacs, 2nd exhale contracts air sacs to drive air into trachea
• Air sacs are thin walled, single cell thick epithelial tissue that communicate w the proximal pneumatic bones (humerus, femur); use the sternum to push and pull air like “bellows”; 8 or 9 in the body
• Since birds breathe by sternum movement, it shouldn’t be restricted during handling
• Air sac cannulas can be placed into the caudal thoracic and abdominal air sacs, allowing the bird to bypass breathing out of the mouth

title: Bird injections and blood collection
detail:
• Blood collection: Right jugular (larger and featherless); brachioulnar or cutaneous ulnar veins on wings, or tibiotarsal or medial metatarsal veins on legs
• Blood collection shouldn’t exceed 1% of the bird’s weight in mL (e.g. 0.6 mL for a 60 gram bird)
• EDTA may lyze cells, so heparin preferred
• IV catheter: Ulnar, medial metatarsal, jugular veins
• IO catheter: Proximal tibia or distal ulna, never in pneumatic bones bc they are connected to respiratory system; vital for small birds and when if IV not possible
• IM: Pectoral muscle
• SC: Inguinal region (largest for fluids), over the pectoral muscle, or in interscapular area, mostly for fluids (warmed in advance); daily maintenance is 50–60 mL/kg/day
• Gavage: Directly into the crop (palpate to confirm, death if in trachea)

title: Bird anesthesia and analgesia
detail:
• Crop must be empty to prevent aspiration (4-12 hr depending on species)
• Premed w midazolam (anxiolytic) or butorphanol (analgesic w sedative properties) and induce w iso (4-5) or sevo (8), preoxygenation recommended
• 1-5.5 mm ET tube for intubation
• Maintenance w iso (1.5-3) or sevo (3-5); regular IPPV (intermittent positive pressure ventilation)
• Butorphanol is the most common opioid for analgesia; hydromorphone and morphine has some effect; B doesn’t; gaba for neuropathic pain; NSAIDs like meloxicam

title: Dietary deficiencies in birds
detail:
• Hypovitaminosis A: Vitamin A deficiency, usually caused by a diet of seed mix only (high in fat, lack A); palate will grow hairlike projections (choanal papillae), plus plantar erosions on the planter surfaces, poor-quality feathering, poor skin, immune-suppression
• Hypocalcemia: Calcium is vital for bone health and muscle contraction; diet of seed mix only can lead to deficiency and result in metabolic bone disease, nutritional hypoparathyroidism, hypocalcemic tetany, egg shell issues
• Thiamine (Vit B1) deficiency: Crucial for cells; may lead to stargazing (due to neck muscle paralysis) and opisthotonos (extreme arching of the back and neck)
• Hypovitaminosis E and selenium deficiency: Cause degeneration of skeletal muscles referred to as white muscle disease

title: Toxicity in birds
detail:
• Zinc toxicity: Found in galvanized wire, pennies, wire clips; signs incl. weight loss, polyuria, polydipsia, anemia, weakness, seizures
• Lead toxicity: Found in batteries, paint, etc.; signs incl.. lethargy, regurgitation, diarrhea, ataxia, wing droop, and leg paresis
• Iron and copper toxicity are uncommon

title: Noninfectious diseases in birds
detail:
• Feather/skin abnormalities can be behavioral or due to hypoparathyroidism, stress, poor nutrition, improper molting, viral etiology, ectoparasites
• Reproductive issues include hernia due to egg binding, dystocia, or chronic egg laying; can also cause peritonitis, dyspnea, lipid disorders, hypocalcemic seizures
• Regurgitation/vomiting may indicate lead poisoning, foreign body, GI tumors, distress
• Toxins include inhalants from paint, pesticides, cookware, teflon, air fresheners, or ingested toxic plants, heavy metals, rodenticide
• Green feces and urates, lethargy, inappetence, ascites, abnormal beak and nails, poor feather quality are indicative of liver disease

title: Infectious diseases in birds – Bacterial diseases
detail:
• Chlamydia psittaci (psittacosis, ornithosis, parrot fever): Bright green feces, respiratory disease, nasal and ocular discharge, lethargy; can be asymptomatic; treated w antibiotics (doxy); zoonotic (flulike in humans) so reportable in some states
• Mycobacteriosis: Chronic weight loss, lethargy; treated w antibiotics; zoonotic
• Coryza: Upper respiratory signs, rhinitis, sinusitis caused by Haemophilus spp and Mycoplasma spp
• Pneumonia and air sacculitis: Lower respiratory tract infections caused by gram-negative bacteria (E. coli, Pseudomonas spp) causing hyperpnea, dyspnea, abdominal breathing, cyanosis; can be asymptomatic; treated w supportive care and antibiotics
• Bacterial enteritis: Diarrhea, dehydration, malodorous feces, and death caused by various bacteria (e.g. Clostridium perfringens)
• 90% of parrot feces are Gram-positive, -neg. indicates infection

title: Infectious diseases in birds – Viral diseases
detail:
• Newcastle disease (Paramyxovirus): Ataxia, opisthotonos, seizures; no cure, only supportive care; poultry vaccine
• Pacheco (herpesvirus): Anorexia, sudden death; no cure; vaccine
• Polyoma (polyomavirus): SC hemorrhage, hepatomegaly, acute death; no cure; vaccine
• Psittacine beak and feather disease (circovirus): thickening of feather shaft (clubbing), feather atypia and loss, beak lesions; no cure but many survive
• Proventricular dilation disease: Dramatically slow GI function, neurologic deficits, death; aka macaw wasting syndrome; no cure; supportive care and NSAIDs

title: Infectious diseases in birds – Mycotic diseases
detail:
• Aspergillosis (Aspergillus fumigatus): Lethargy, anorexia, respiratory distress, death, commonly in immunosuppressed or stressed birds; a secondary disease; treated w amphotericin B, itraconazole, terbinafine, voriconazole
• Candidiasis (Candida albicans): Gray or white lesions in the oral cavity, esophagus, crop
• Avian gastric yeast (aka ornithogaster or megabacteria caused by Macrorhabdus ornithogaster): Weight loss, failure to thrive, abnormal GI motility, undigested feed in feces; can be asymptomatic

title: Parasites in birds
detail:
• Ectoparasites include lice (only Mallophaga spp) and mites (leg and face mites Knemidocoptes spp, tracheal mites Sternostoma tracheacolum)
• Endoparasites include:
• Nematodes (ascarids, gapeworm)
• Protozoa (coccidiosis, trichomoniasis, hemosporeridia)
• Cestodes and trematodes are uncommon

title: Reptilians
detail:
• Slower metabolic rate than mammals, meaning healing is slower
• Have either scales (squamates like snakes, lizards) or scutes (chelonians, like turtle, crocodile); top shell of chelonians is called carapace, bottom shell is plastron, both made up of keratin
• Plastron is concave in most male species; used to help mount during mating
• Period of ecdysis (shedding)
• Lizards can shed tails ben captured (autotomy); new tail will lack vertebrae; large femoral pores in lizards are indicative of maleness
• Esophagus, stomach, small and large intestines, rectum, cloaca present—no diaphragm, all organs in the coelomic cavity
• No (or small) left lung in snakes; tidal volume is controlled by body cavity pressure in snakes and lizards
• No loop of Henle in urinary system

title: Reptilians (cont).
detail:
• Poikilothermic—rely on environmental temp to maintain body temp and metabolic processes; humidity is important as well
• 3-chambered hearts (2 atria, 1 ventricle) except crocodiles; nucleated RBCs
• Blood volume is 5-8% of body weight
• UV (A and B) radiation lights required for vit D3 synthesis and calcium metabolism (other than carnivorous lizards)
• Parietal (third) eye on the dorsal portion of the head acts as a photoreceptor, helping to regulate hormone production and thermoregulatory behavior in lizards
• Snakes are unique in having azurophils, which are monocytes w small azurophilic granules in the cytoplasm
• Chromatophores are specialized cells that allow color change; specific to the chameleon and anole species
• Lizards have poor sense of detecting heat, so all heat should be outside cage (no heated rocks) to avoid burns

title: Ecdysis vs. dysecdysis
detail:
• Ecdysis: Normal shedding of skin; healthy
• Normal signs include anorexia, striking at owner, hissing, a blue-opaque coloring to the eyes and skin
• Dysecdysis: Abnormal or incomplete shedding of skin; extremity necrosis (toes or tail tip) common, causes constriction, acting as a rubber band; amputation is often necessary

title: Reptilian injections and blood collection
detail:
• Blood collection: Ventral tail vein for lizards, snakes, chelonians; jugular possible for chelonians and cardiac sampling is easiest for snakes
• IV catheter: Jugular vein in chelonians, caudal tail vein in lizards, coccygeal or right jugular in snakes most common
• IO catheter: Used more than IV due to ease; proximal tibia or femur w local anesthetic
• IM: Given in the front half of the body due to renal portal system to avoid nephrotoxicity or premature elimination; front legs or pectorals for chelonians, front legs or epaxial muscles for lizards, dorsal epaxial muscles for snakes
• SC: Mostly intracoelomically; always warmed

title: Reptilian anesthesia and analgesia
detail:
• No mask induction because they hold their breaths
• Ketamine or lower dose ketamine w midazolam or dexmedetomidine are common premeds and sedatives
• IV Propofol for induction, alfaxalone used too
• Respiratory depression common under anesthesia; manual ventilation necessary
• Butorphanol for minor pain, buprenorphine for minor to moderate pain, oxymorphone for moderate to severe pain; NSAIDs (melaxicam, ketoprofen), local anesthetics (lido and bupivacaine), tramadol and gaba are also used
• Doppler is the most common tool for HR; stethoscope doesn’t work well due to shell/scales, pulse is impossible to palpate

title: Reptilian diseases
detail:
• Poor husbandry can cause anorexia, hypothermia, decreased immune function, dysecdysis
• Secondary hyperparathyroidism (metabolic bone disease or hypocalcemia): Caused by inadequate calcium in the diet and not enough UVB exposure; signs include long bone fractures, thick swollen jaws and thighs due to fibrous osteodystrophy, problems w egg laying, tremors, seizures; treated w calcium therapy, UV B light, diet correction
• Hypovitaminosis A: Caused by lack of beta carotene and vitamin A; signs include palpebral edema, conjunctivitis, anorexia, dysecdysis, aural abscess, URIs; treated w vit A injections, diet correction, supportive care

title: Reptilian diseases – Bacterial and viral diseases
detail:
• Somatitis/mouth rot: Caused by Pseudomonas spp and Aeromonas spp in case of suboptimal temp and humidity, poor management, malnutrition, trauma
• Pneumonia: Caused commonly by bacteria (but also virus, fungus) in cases of poor husbandry and poor management in snakes and chelonians; signs include dyspnea, open mouth or audible breathing, buoyancy problems
• Septicemia: Caused by variety of bacteria incl. Pseudomonas spp and Aeromonas spp; signs include skin necrosis, SC abscesses, lethargy; treated w broad-spectrum gram-negative antibiotics, surgical excision and debridement, supportive care as needed
• Septicemic cutaneous ulcer disease: Caused by variety of gram-negative bacteria like Citrobacter spp in aquatic turtles; signs incl. cutaneous ulceration, anorexia, septicemia, death
• Salmonellosis: Normal in flora—concern due to zoonosis
• Viral encephalitis: Inclusion body disease in snakes; neurological signs
• Herpesvirus: Iguanas and turtles; severe respiratory issues

title: Reptilian diseases – Mycotic diseases and parasites
detail:
• Yellow fungus disease: Dermal infection that can become systemic and cause death; common in young bearded dragons
• Endoparasites: Cryptosporidium, coccidia, entamoeba, cestodes, trematodes, nematodes
• Ectoparasites: Ticks common in snakes and tortoises, mites common in snakes and iguanas

title: Rabbits (Lagomorpha)
detail:
• Unique reproductive tract w a duplex uterus and two cervices
• Predominant WBCs are lymphocytes and heterophils (equivalent to neutrophils)
• Neoplasms aren’t common in rabbits, except uterine adenocarcinoma (common in unspayed female rabbits older than 4); signs include hematuria, frank blood at the end of urination, depression, anorexia, dehydration
• Cecotropes/night feces are the soft feces that are excreted and then consumed to additionally digest nutrients
• Atropine not recommended (not effective on 30-50%)
• Treponema paraluiscuniculi is responsible for syphilis; transmitted via venereal contact bw rabbits, diagnosed w a skin biopsy with silver staining
• At risk of pregnancy toxemia during last week of gestation; cause unknown, but stress, obesity, low-calorie intake, environmental changes contribute
• Encephalitozoon cuniculi is a common disease that cause neurological signs in pet rabbits
• Are monogastric hindgut fermenters; diet should be hay and dark leafy greens w small amount of pellets; hay important for healthy weight, dental disease, and GI health

title: Rodents
detail:
• Guinea pigs have primarily Gram-positive GI flora; very sensitive to antibiotics like penicillin, ampicillin, clindamycin, lincomycin; Clostridium difficile is the most common bacteria associated w enterotoxemia, although other bacteria can cause issues (to a smaller extent) when wrong antibiotics are given
• Bordetella bronchiseptica along w poor husbandry and increased humidity causes bacterial pneumonia in guinea pigs
• Penile prolapse is common in chinchillas; caused by fur accumulation around the base, which can be removed using saline, lubricant, and a swab to pull the fur away gently; signs include excessive grooming, straining to urinate, repeatedly cleaning penis, production of small spots of urine
• Fur slip is a natural predatory response in chinchillas—large amounts of fur can be released during scruffing when scared
• Wet tail is a life-threatening diarrheal disease is hamsters; caused by bacterial infections, stress, or a poor diet; signs include diarrhea, matting around the tail, lethargy, hunched abdomen
• In hamsters, a lean diet, low body weight, handling of the mother/young, and decreased ambient temperature can lead to cannibalism

title: Sugar gliders
detail:
• Marsupials; arboreal
• Cloaca similar to birds and reptiles, where GI, urinary, and reproductive tracts are empty
• Jugular vein, cranial vena cava, and medial tibial artery are used for collection of larger blood samples
• Calcium can’t be absorbed properly w/out adequate dietary calcium, vitamin D, and phosphorus, leading to hypocalcemia
• Nutritional osteodystrophy common; signs incl. acute onset of hind limb paresis or paralysis; caused by feeding a diet low in calcium and vitamin D3.
